Award.AwardTitle: Development and assessment of mobile geo-referenced games for geoscience education using the Grand Canyon as a virtual laboratory

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project is developing and assessing mobile-based learning games for introductory geoscience courses based on geological features of the Grand Canyon. Using smartphones with geo-referencing capability, students physically navigate a scaled version of the virtual landscape, observing, collecting data and solving problems based on field photographs, maps and other information, with scoring and rewards native to the gaming environment. Student use provides a large dataset to assess student learning and game design. The intellectual merit of the project lies in its innovative approach to leveraging recent technological and educational advances to improve learning and engagement of the current generation of students who take introductory geoscience courses, particularly where real field trips are not possible. Broader impacts include the dissemination of the games to a wide range of institutions and student audiences. The educational research of the games' impact also offers insight into strategies for effective use of mobile-based games in the geosciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There is a well-documented and nationally reported trend of declining interest, low persistence, and lack of diversity among U.S. students pursuing Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM) disciplines. In the case of the geosciences, a primary contributor is that college-level introductory courses simply fail to inspire most students. It is clear from previous studies that field trips are often the most impactful component of geoscience courses, and it is frequently hands-on field experiences that draw students into a geoscience career. Yet, introductory geoscience courses are typically taught in the traditional form of a lecture and a complementary lab, and are commonly large enrollment sections. High enrollment can logistically rule out class field trips, it increases the sense of student anonymity, can exclude students with physical limitations, and ultimately reduces the potential for inspiring students. Our research helps explore solutions to these issues using everyday technology that exists in most students’ hands.

 

We investigate the potential of the unique learning experience of field trips being simulated through the use of smartphones and tablet computers. Three new software applications (apps) for both iOS and Android mobile devices were developed for augmented reality (AR) fieldtrips to Grand Canyon, designed to cover core concepts for incorporation into higher education curricula and to be accessible to students of diverse locations and physical abilities (Figure 1). These educational apps are freely available at both the Apple and Android online marketplaces. We tested these modules for their impact on student interest in the geosciences and on student learning of geoscience concepts at five institutions representing the full range of secondary education institutions.

 

The results of this study indicate that students completing all three modules became significantly (statistically speaking) more interested in learning the geosciences than those who did not (Figure 2). With respect to gains in student learning, our results are more subtle. Certainly, these first-generation AR field trip modules do not detract from student learning, and they do, in fact, contribute to enhanced learning in the cases of particular modules and certain institutions. We find a notable lack of correlation between learning gains and ethnicity or gender, suggesting that these AR field trip modules are indeed accessible across a broad swath of student demographics.

 

These results, as published in a PhD Dissertation and three peer-reviewed journal articles (two still in press at the time of this writing), provide evidence for the intellectual merit of this study. Broader impacts include the freely and publicly available educational apps themselves (search for “GCX” at the iTunes or Android marketplaces), the involvement and development of new teaching strategies with partner educators and training of students in the study, and the potential step forward we contribute in utilizing emerging technologies in STEM education. We conclude that AR field trips--conducted on the mobile devices nearly all students have--will inevitably become a growing and increasingly effective geoscience-education tool. We show that it clearly increases student engagement and, with further development, they have the potential to improve student learning. Such educational technology provides a flexible, budget-friendly, and broadly inclusive approach for educators.
